Authors: Steven J. Wagstaff, Brian P. J. Molloy
Title:
Incomplete species coalescence and paraphyly in the
Marlborough rock daisies (Pachystegia, Astereae, Asteraceae)
Keywords:
Astereae, Asteraceae, BEAST*, coalescence, divergence time
estimate, gene tree, New Zealand, Pachystegia, paraphyly, species
tree
Abstract:
The Marlborough rock daisies are members of a remarkable
evolutionary radiation in New Zealand. They form a monophyletic group
with a restricted distribution in the north-eastern corner of the South
Island. Three species are currently accepted, though distinct phenotypes
are recognised that may represent additional as yet formally described
entities. We used concatenated and coalescent analyses of multi-locus
data to infer phylogenetic relationships and to visualize a species
tree. Our results show populations of Pachystegia rufa and P. minor are
nested within the more widely distributed species P. insignis, which is
paraphyletic in our analyses. There is discordance among the gene trees
and species coalescence is incomplete. Limited gene flow occurs among
the three species. Hybrids persist in narrow zones of contact, but
apparently do not compete in the ecological niche of the parental
species. Dated chronograms show a sharp increase in the rate of
diversification during the last 2 million years, which coincides with
uplift of the coastal Kaikoura Ranges. The accumulation of unique
alleles preceded the evolution of barriers to gene flow, so the
estimated divergence times in the gene trees are older than in the
inferred species tree. Genetic drift and strong selection in small
geographically isolated populations have contributed to recent
speciation in the rock daisies. We discuss the taxonomic implications of
paraphyly in this rapidly evolving insular plant group.
